paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Whether the rocky exoplanet TRAPPIST-1 b retains an atmosphere and what its composition might be, based on day-night heat transport and spectral signatures.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Observed system
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: One rocky exoplanet with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: One rocky exoplanet (TRAPPIST-1 b) with phase-resolved thermal spectra observed by JWST MIRI.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Null scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Bare-rock, no-atmosphere model with minimal heat redistribution used as a comparison baseline.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere model with significant greenhouse gas absorption and carbon dioxide signatures.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Oxidized composition with weaker CO2 signature constraints compared to the CO2-rich model.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, cloud treatment) affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
